questions.question_text: How do cloud deployments differ from on-premises deployments?

choices.A: Cloud deployments require longer implementation times than on-premises deployments.
choices.C: Cloud deployments have lower upfront costs than on-premises deployments.
choices.D: Cloud deployments require less frequent upgrades than on-premises deployments.
choices.B: Cloud deployments are more customizable than on-premises deployments.

Selected Answer: DE
Guys let's use common sense, what solution costs 50 thousand dollars and it will make all devices point to it and if it fails your entire network fails ? think about it just from the logic common sense point of view and then answer. No devices will not lose connectivity if DNA Center goes down.

Selected Answer: DE
If you have Cisco SD-Access implemented and DNA Center becomes unreachable then the wired and wireless
network will continue to forward packets as usual. There will be no impact to network performance or behavior.
Yes you will be able to SSH / telnet / console into switches and wireless network infrastructure as usual. For the
period DNA Center is unreachable, Assurance data will be lost, and you will not be able to make configuration
changes to the Cisco SD-Access network

enterprise equipment has separate control plane and data plane and the data plan stays working when the control plane fails. You just can't make any config changes until the control plane is fixed. This works mainly because the control plane is running on CPU while the data plane is using ASICs.

Selected Answer: CD
If you have Cisco SD-Access implemented and DNA Center becomes unreachable then the wired and wireless
network will continue to forward packets as usual. There will be no impact to network performance or behavior.
Yes you will be able to SSH / telnet / console into switches and wireless network infrastructure as usual. For the
period DNA Center is unreachable, Assurance data will be lost, and you will not be able to make configuration
changes to the Cisco SD-Access network
If Cisco DNA Center loses connectivity to devices in the SD-Access fabric, it will affect both new and already connected users.

comments.content:
When Cisco DNA Center loses connectivity to devices in the SD-Access fabric, it can no longer communicate with the controllers that are responsible for managing user access and network policies. This means that new users will be unable to connect to the network, and existing users may experience disruptions in their connectivity.

The existing connected users may not be disconnected but their session may be affected by this loss of connectivity, for example:

They may experience a loss of network services, such as Internet access or access to specific resources.
They may experience a decrease in network performance.
They may be unable to authenticate to the network or access specific resources.
It is important to monitor the health of the Cisco DNA Center and the SD-Access fabric to ensure that connectivity is maintained and to quickly identify and resolve any issues that arise.

questions.question_text: Which two results occur if Cisco DNA Center loses connectivity to devices in the SD-Access fabric? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Cisco DNA Center is unable to collect monitoring data in Assurance
choices.B: Already connected users are unaffected but new users cannot connect
choices.C: All devices reload after detecting loss of connection to Cisco DNA Center

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The connection between SW1 and SW2 is not operational. Which two actions resolve the issue? (Choose two.)

choices.C: configure switchport mode access on SW2
choices.D: configure switchport mode trunk on SW2
choices.E: configure switchport mode dynamic desirable on SW2

discussion.content:
I really see people with 0 xp in real working env.....
 the the question asks which two actions - one OR the other... even if you exclude answers you end up with - dynamic desirable and static trunk... stop misleading the people ...

comments.content:
The question is completely broken. SW1 cannot be dynamic auto and nonegotiate:

(config-if)#switchport nonegotiate
Command rejected: Conflict between 'nonegotiate' and 'dynamic' status.

So then we do not know what they intended it to be. Either SW1 is supposed to be administrative mode dynamic auto with negotiation turned on, or it is supposed to be administrative mode trunk with negotiation turned off. If we assume auto then it will be DE if we assume it is turned off then only D works. So it must be that negotiation is supposed to be turned on in SW1, or the answers have a typo.
Im sorry mister know it all.

not necessarily, cisco has a lot of exam questions that ask you the same: "Which two actions resolve the issue?" and the answer to most of them points to the need of two actions chained, one after another, one AND another... so i conclude this is a classical cisco´s tricky question.. and here memorization is probably the best learning method..

discussion.content:
Look at SW1: it is dynamic auto AND also Negotiation off - no such thing!!!!!!!!
By default it is dynamic auto, then you can NOT disable negotiation. Unless you static it to trunk, then you can disable negotiation.
Command rejected: Conflict between 'nonegotiate' and 'dynamic' status.

comments.content: I tried to lab this. I can't get the configuration to match what the question is displaying. This question is dumb as hell.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
I think the question is which 2 commands can fix the issue. (Think about it)

Selected Answer: BD
SW1's negotiation of trunking is set to off. This means SW1 will operate in its current operational mode (trunk) without participating in DTP.

Given that SW1 won't participate in DTP, it is appropriate to set SW2's mode of trunking negotiation to 'nonegotiate.' Finally, to successfully establish a trunk link between the two switches we need to explicitly set SW1's port to 'trunk.' `Dynamic desirable` mode only works if the other side can exchange DTP frames, which is not the case in our scenario.
D and E

Selected Answer: DE
Current Community vote distribution (2024-07-15):
DE (35%)
BE (27%)
BD (25%)
AE (10%)

75% of people agree with answer E. Correct: desirable/auto = trunk
60% of people agree with answer D. Correct: trunk/auto = trunk
52% of people agree with answer B. Wrong: encapsulation is already dot1q
10% of people agree with answer A. Wrong: negotiation is already disabled

The output is confusing, because both sides have 'dynamic auto' configured and the operational mode is 'trunk'. You would expect both sides won't initiate to become a trunk and this results in operational mode 'static access'.

D and E should be correct, but only when choosing one of these at the same time.

Selected Answer: AE
A&E IS Correct Answer

ANSWER(D,E)
The issue between SW1 and SW2 lies in the trunk negotiation mode. The administrative mode on both switches is set to "dynamic auto," which means that neither switch actively attempts to form a trunk; they both wait for the other side to initiate.

Answer D doesn't seem to be valid. According to network lessons when "administrative trunking encapsulation" is set to negotiate(can be seen on SW2) switchport mode trunk will return error:
SW2(config-if)#switchport mode trunk
Command rejected: An interface whose trunk encapsulation is "Auto" can not be configured to "trunk" mode.

The no switchport nonegotiate command enables DTP negotiation

SW1 Negotiation Off, which prevents DTP negotiation packets from being sent out the interface. 
So we need to re-enable it with the “no switchport nonegotiate” command.

so the answers for the prvided answers above are A & E

comments.content: On older IOS devices, that is true, but after version 15 of IOS (I believe), it is assumed that you want 802.1q encapsulation, so you no longer have to specify the encapsulation of a trunk link.

discussion.content:
For me, there is only one correct answer is E. You can't define the mode as trunk without identifying the encapsulation as specifically either ISL or DOT1Q.
Configuring "nonegotiate" won't allow you to configure switch mode trunk, even if the question implies one or the other, B or D solve the issue. 
The only way to get this trunk link to work is by configuring dynamic desireable on SW2.
I tried a lot of combinations, but non get me to the point where the exhibit shows

Official cert: A static trunk port attempts to establish and negotiate a trunk port with a neighbor by
default. However, the interface configuration command switchport nonegotiate prevents
that port from forming a trunk port with a dynamic desirable or dynamic auto switch port.
So if you configure switchport mode trunk on SW2, trunk is up.
Correct answer DE

Dynamic Auto + Dynamic Auto != Trunk (No trunk formed)
Dynamic Auto + Dynamic Desirable = Trunk (Forms Trunk) - Means E is correct

switchport nonegotiate: Prevents the interface from generating DTP frames. You can use this command only when the interface switchport mode is access or trunk. You must manually configure the neighboring interface as a trunk interface to establish a trunk link.

Switch 1 interface is already a trunk and Dynamic Auto so trunk forms!

The article says:
"DTP manages trunk negotiation only if the port on the neighbor switch is configured in a trunk mode that supports DTP."
SW1 is set to "Negotiation of trunk: Off" This leaves us with option D) "configure switchport mode trunk on SW2".
In this case we can proceed with B) configure switchport nonegotiate on SW2. This is recommended, too. 
Same article:
"A general best practice is to set the interface to trunk and nonegotiate when a trunk link is required."

switchport mode dynamic desirable: Makes the interface actively attempt to convert the link to a trunk link. The interface becomes a trunk interface if the neighboring interface is set to trunk, desirable, or auto mode.7 apr 2014

Selected Answer: BE
BE
No negotiation and dynamic desirable

Selected Answer: DE
To bring the trunk UP you need “dynamic desirable” mode OR “switchport mode trunk” to activate the trunk

switchport mode trunk says: “Always trunk on this end, and I will send DTP to attempt to negotiate a trunk on the other end.”

switchport nonegotiate says: “Do not send or respond to DTP from this end. Disable all DTP on this port.”

switchport mode dynamic desirable says: “Ask the other end to trunk using DTP and trunk if the negotiation succeeds. If DTP negotiation fails then become an access port.”

switchport mode dynamic auto says: “If the other end asks me to be a trunk with DTP, then become a trunk, but I wont initiate any negotitation from this end. If no one asks me to become a trunk then I will become an access port.”

src == https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/disable-dtp-on-a-switch/td-p/3328521

switchport mode access says: “Never trunk on this end and never send DTP messages"

switchport trunk encapsulation says: “Do not negotiate the trunk protocol with DTP. Only use the trunk protocol specified in this command (isl or dot1q).

Selected Answer: CE
The commands: "switchport nonegotiate" & "switchport mode trunk" won't work while the switch is in dynamic mode, so the only way to restart the trunk here, is to use the commands: "switchport mode access", followed by the command: "switchport mode dynamic desirable". 
- tested in GNS3

If we turn off DTP with "nonegotiate" and configure "trunk" on SW2, then on SW1 we would have to configure "trunk" to establish a trunk link (but we see it's already "dynamic auto").

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A company has an internal wireless network with a hidden SSID and RADIUS-based client authentication for increased security. An employee attempts to manually add the company network to a laptop, but the laptop does not attempt to connect to the network. The regulatory domains of the access points and the laptop are identical. Which action resolves this issue?

choices.D: Limit the enabled wireless channels on the laptop to the maximum channel range that is supported by the access points.
choices.A: Ensure that the "Connect even if this network is not broadcasting" option is selected.
choices.C: Use the empty string as the hidden SSID network name.
choices.B: Change the security type to WPA2-Personal AES.

discussion.content: Apparently becoming an network engineer requires you to be a desktop windows admin now
The worst questions are the ones where the answer is common sense but since they weren't ever discussed you think that it's gotta be a trick
Question present on 1.1

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
the answer is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct:
https://windowsreport.com/connect-hidden-wi-fi-network-windows-10/

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
I think both A and C are correct

why not C?
Answer A is correct definitely, but is Answer C also correct as well?

Selected Answer: A
RIB is derived from the control plane, it is not used for forwarding. Every protocol such as OSPF, EIGRP, BGP has its own RIB and select their best candidates to try to install to global RIB so that it can then be selected for forwarding. If this is implemented through totally separate RIBs or one big RIB with partitions I am not aware of.

 

FIB is used for forwarding, like Erick explained the information is derived from the RIB and from adjacency tables so that the packet can be rewritten with the correct encapsulation.
see https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/question/0D53i00000KssjfCAB/routing-rib-vs-fib

questions.question_text: How do the RIB and the FIB differ?

choices.B: FIB is derived from the control plane, and the RIB is derived from the data plane.
choices.C: RIB contains the interface for a destination, and the FIB contains the next hop information.
choices.A: RIB is derived from the control plane, and the FIB is derived from the RIB.
choices.D: FIB contains routes learned through a dynamic routing protocol and the RIB contains routes that are static or directly connected.
